vclaim: Donald Trump says that health-care policies "have left millions more Americans uninsured since taking office."
date: stated on March 26, 2019 in a tweet:
title: Yeah, more people aren't insured since Donald Trump took office, but be cliché with specific numbers.
text: The decision of the Trump Administration to request the Federal Court to declare the entire Affordable Care Act unconstitutional has overthrown the Democrats. According to one estimate, some 20 million people depend on the law for their health care. Presidential candidate Julian Castro, who served as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development of the Obama Administration, said that President Donald Trump's last step was at the forefront of his broader policy of undermining President Barack Obama's health-care programme. "Donald Trump is doubling on the health-care agenda, which has left millions more Americans uninsured since taking office," wrote Castro on Twitter on March 26. "As President, I will expand access to quality health care and make universal coverage my first legislative priority." In this fact-finding, we have focused on whether there are millions more who have not been insured since Trump took office. In a major referendum in Gallup, the Castro team referred to the results achieved in the Gallup National Health and Welfare Index in January 2019. 13.7 per cent of Americans said they were not insured in the fourth quarter of 2018. "Today's level is higher in more than four years, and well above a low point of 10.9 per cent reached in 2016," the report said. "An increase of 2.8 percentage points because this decrease represents a net increase of about 7 million adults without health insurance." So this is a "millions" of Castro, but before that we found Gallup to be the weirdest, largely because the uninsured were undervalued by anyone in 2016. From this low point, any increase appears to be greater. So we've been looking for more sources. According to the latest figures from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, between 2016 and the first nine months of 2018, the number of uninsured persons increased by 1.3 million. This figure comes from the National Survey of Health Interviews, a long-term research programme that received responses from a group of more than 61,000 people. "The National Health Interview Survey is the gold standard in terms of measuring health insurance registration at the national level," said the Health Policy Analyst of Rand Christine Epner. My only warning is that the most recent data do not include the abolition of the penalty for individual jurisdiction, which entered into force on 1 January 2019. So we can see more erosion." The Republicans abolished the requirement of universal access to insurance as part of the Tax and Job Reduction Act 2017. Chris Kondiloshi, a former officer of the Republican Senate Committee on Health Care Benefits, also trusts the data of the Centre for Disease Control. On January 13, 2021, the distinguished fact-finding bloggers announced in a story in which General David H. Berger, commander of the United States Navy, rejected Nancy Belusi's request to use the Marines for the security of the inauguration, saying, "We are not working for you." "The slight rise is not millions, but you cannot be ashamed of the fact that there are now some uninsured people with insurance in 2016." The Government survey found that the uninsured rate rose from 12.4 per cent in 2016 to 13 per cent in September 2018. The analysts of the Centre for Disease Control did not say that the increase was of statistical importance. On the other hand, the latest results are preliminary, and the authors of the CDC noted that "the initial estimates for persons without health insurance coverage are generally 0.1 to 0.3 percentage points lower than the final estimates." In short, the best survey available shows an increase in the number of insured persons, and the rate of non-insurance can be higher when the final figures appear. Other surveys find evidence of an increase in the New York-based Commonwealth Fund, a special health policy group, which also measures insurance coverage. According to her work, about 2 million people lost health coverage under Trump. A major research effort by the Urban Institute has found small, albeit statistically significant, evidence that progress towards wider coverage has stalled and may be in a reverse direction. An analysis of "US health insurance coverage: 2017" conducted by the Census Bureau showed an increase in the number of 492,000 uninsured persons between 2017 and 2016. Only one year has passed, but the trend is rising. Whatever the increase in the number of insured persons, Trump ' s influence generally links the trend towards republican policies. There is no doubt that Trump and the Republicans in Congress have worked hard and almost eliminated Obama's care. Trump has cancelled some $10 billion of payments to insurance companies, a step that has led to higher insurance premiums, although they have since been reduced. The Department has made provision for registration by shortening the contribution period and reducing the marketing budget by 90 per cent. However, access to Obama ' s care plans declined by only 2.6 per cent between 2018 and 2019. The total number of registrations was over 11.4 million. "Trap and Congress took many actions that could have an upward effect on the uninsured rate," said Cynthia Cox with the Kaiser Family Foundation. But the actual impact of the Trump management policies on the unsecured rate is still an open question. Our judgment, Castro, has said that millions of other people are not covered by insurance as a result of Trump's policies. An opinion poll estimated a jump of 7 million people without health insurance. However, the most reliable government surveys found an increase of less than 1.3 million. Whatever the role of Republican politics, there is broad agreement that the number has increased. Castro said it was millions. The best data says it's more like 1.3 million. Castro has the right direction, but the numbers don't fully support him on the details. We're assessing this claim half right.
